microcontents.title: Understanding Cognitive Bias: Perception, Memory, and Decision-Making
microcontents.description: An educational video exploring the mental mechanisms behind cognitive bias formation, explaining how systematic errors in cognitive processes (memory, perception, information processing) lead to biased decision-making, illustrated through gaming examples and psychological experiments.
learningOutcomes: Acquire knowledge of basic cognitive processes (memory, perception, information processing) involved in bias formation
Make meaning of how mental mechanisms systematically create errors in human reasoning and decision-making
Transfer understanding to analyze concrete cases and identify specific cognitive processes responsible for different bias types
Recognize the unconscious and systematic nature of cognitive bias development in real-world contexts

microcontents.title: Why does the human brain systematically develop cognitive biases during decision-making?
microcontents.description: Explores how basic cognitive processes like memory, attention, and perception create mental shortcuts (heuristics) that lead to systematic thinking errors and cognitive biases in daily decision-making.
learningOutcomes: Identify the three basic cognitive processes (memory, attention, perception) involved in bias formation
Explain how heuristics function as mental shortcuts that lead to systematic errors
Analyze concrete examples of how memory creates availability bias and attention creates confirmation bias
Interpret the evolutionary purpose of cognitive biases and their modern implications

microcontents.title: Dr. Lisa's Diagnosis: Cognitive Bias Case Study Analysis
microcontents.description: Interactive case study that examines how availability heuristic and confirmation bias influenced a physician's diagnostic process, with reflection questions to analyze cognitive mechanisms autonomously.
learningOutcomes: Analyze real-world scenarios to identify specific cognitive processes at work
Autonomously recognize how availability heuristic influences professional decision-making
Evaluate how selective attention and memory priming contribute to confirmation bias
Propose strategies to mitigate cognitive biases in professional contexts

microcontents.title: The Brain's Decision-Making Toolkit: Complete Guide to Cognitive Bias Mechanisms
microcontents.description: Comprehensive learning document that systematically explains cognitive processes, provides concrete examples like availability bias, and includes practical activities for autonomous analysis of bias formation.
learningOutcomes: Define and differentiate the four core cognitive processes involved in bias formation (heuristics, attention, perception, memory)
Analyze concrete examples to understand how availability bias emerges from memory limitations and accessibility
Evaluate systematic factors (energy saving, processing speed, memory constraints) that make biases inevitable
Apply bias recognition skills to autonomous analysis of professional scenarios like recruitment decisions

microcontents.title: 10 Key Concepts in Cognitive Psychology Explained
microcontents.description: Educational video that systematically presents fundamental cognitive psychology concepts including perception, attention, memory, and cognitive biases, providing essential foundational knowledge for understanding mental processes.
learningOutcomes: Define the three core cognitive processes: perception, attention, and memory
Identify how schemas organize and interpret information based on prior knowledge
Recognize cognitive biases as systematic errors affecting decision making and judgments
Distinguish between different types of memory (short-term vs long-term) and their functions

microcontents.title: Quiz: Cognitive Biases and Mental Processes
microcontents.description: Progressive reflective quiz that guides learners through understanding cognitive bias formation, from basic concepts to personal application, culminating in autonomous analysis of personal decision-making errors.
learningOutcomes: Identify how heuristics based on perception, attention, and memory create availability bias
Interpret the systematic nature of cognitive biases as predictable, recurring distortions
Map specific cognitive processes (perception, attention, memory) to corresponding bias types
Analyze personal decision-making errors to autonomously identify involved cognitive processes and biases

microcontents.title: Analytical Quiz: Cognitive Biases and Mental Processes
microcontents.description: Problem-based quiz presenting concrete scenarios where learners must autonomously identify cognitive processes and biases, from selective attention in meetings to evolutionary advantages of biased thinking.
learningOutcomes: Autonomously analyze concrete workplace scenarios to identify selective attention mechanisms
Independently diagnose perceptual biases in evaluation situations and predict their consequences
Apply memory availability concepts to explain distorted frequency judgments in personal experiences
Distinguish between System 1 and System 2 thinking in emergency decision-making contexts
Evaluate evolutionary origins of cognitive biases and assess their adaptive vs maladaptive functions

microcontents.title: Basic Cognitive Processes Behind Cognitive Biases
microcontents.description: Comprehensive theoretical document explaining the fundamental mental mechanisms that influence thinking, covering attention, perception, memory, and dual-process theory as foundations for understanding cognitive biases.
learningOutcomes: Define cognitive biases and explain their origin from mental shortcuts
Identify the four basic cognitive processes: attention, perception, memory, and thinking
Explain how selective attention leads to confirmation bias and information filtering
Describe how perception constructs reality through top-down processing
Recognize memory's selective and reconstructive nature and its impact on availability bias
Distinguish between System 1 (fast, intuitive) and System 2 (slow, deliberate) thinking processes

microcontents.title: Bias Hunter: Case-Based Analysis of Cognitive Errors
microcontents.description: Structured practical task guiding students through independent analysis of real-world judgment errors, requiring identification of cognitive biases, underlying mental processes, and mitigation strategies through case study methodology.
learningOutcomes: Independently select and analyze real-life cases involving cognitive judgment errors
Systematically identify specific cognitive biases in authentic scenarios from news, media, or historical events
Map underlying cognitive mechanisms (attention, memory, perception) to observed bias manifestations
Construct logical cause-and-effect explanations connecting mental processes to systematic errors
Develop and propose practical mitigation strategies including critical thinking techniques and decision-making frameworks
Present analysis findings in structured format through written reports or multimedia presentations

microcontents.title: Cognitive Shortcuts and Mental Processes: A Conversational Introduction
microcontents.description: Informal dialogue between two speakers exploring how cognitive shortcuts work, covering attention limitations, perception biases, and memory reconstruction through relatable examples and everyday language.
learningOutcomes: Recognize that the brain uses cognitive shortcuts to process information quickly
Understand how limited attention leads to selective focus and confirmation bias
Explain why perception is subjective and influenced by expectations and past experiences
Recognize that memory is reconstructive rather than a perfect recording
Identify how availability bias makes recent or vivid memories disproportionately influential
Develop initial awareness of personal cognitive biases through relatable examples

microcontents.title: To Buy or Not to Buy? The Washing Machine Dilemma
microcontents.description: Interactive scenario simulating everyday consumer decision-making, guiding learners through analysis of cognitive biases in purchasing choices with practical reflection questions and bias mitigation strategies.
learningOutcomes: Interpret how memory, attention, and perception influence everyday purchasing decisions
Identify familiarity bias, priming effects, and confirmation bias in simulated consumer scenarios
Analyze the interaction between cognitive processes and systematic decision-making errors
Apply bias awareness strategies to improve future decision-making in real-world contexts
Develop practical techniques for objective comparison and emotional regulation in choices
Transfer learning to advise others while avoiding personal bias projection

microcontents.title: System 1 vs System 2: Understanding Kahneman's Dual-Process Theory
microcontents.description: Educational video explaining Daniel Kahneman's dual-process theory from 'Thinking, Fast and Slow', contrasting intuitive System 1 thinking with deliberate System 2 thinking, including their characteristics, advantages, and limitations.
learningOutcomes: Distinguish between System 1 (fast, automatic) and System 2 (slow, deliberate) thinking modes
Identify characteristics and functions of each cognitive system in daily life situations
Recognize the advantages and limitations of both thinking systems
Understand how System 1 can lead to biases and judgment errors through heuristics
Explain why System 2 is prone to mental fatigue and cognitive avoidance
Develop awareness of when to engage System 2 for critical thinking and rational decision-making

microcontents.title: Five Examples of Clever Use of Cognitive Biases in Product Design
microcontents.description: UX design video demonstrating practical applications of cognitive biases in digital product design through real-world examples including scarcity effect, Ikea effect, social proof, halo effect, and foot-in-the-door technique.
learningOutcomes: Apply scarcity effect principles to create urgency in digital product features
Implement Ikea effect by designing customizable user experiences that increase perceived value
Utilize social proof mechanisms to build credibility and influence user behavior
Leverage halo effect through strategic brand associations and endorsements
Design foot-in-the-door sequences that break complex tasks into manageable steps
Integrate cognitive bias principles into practical UX/product design solutions

microcontents.title: Cognitive Biases That Affect UX Designers: Overconfidence, Framing, and Status Quo
microcontents.description: UX design video examining how cognitive biases influence designers' decision-making processes, covering overconfidence effect, framing bias, and status quo bias with practical strategies for bias-aware design practice.
primaryConcepts: status quo bias in design decisions
learningOutcomes: Recognize how overconfidence effect increases with expertise and affects design decision-making
Identify framing bias in usability data interpretation and its impact on design conclusions
Understand how status quo bias leads to resistance in removing or changing existing design features
Apply research-based approaches to counteract reliance on intuition and assumptions
Develop strategies for examining data from multiple perspectives to avoid framing effects
Cultivate willingness to question existing design elements and embrace iterative improvement

microcontents.title: Heuristics: Mental Shortcuts and Their Hidden Flaws
microcontents.description: Educational video exploring how heuristics serve as cognitive shortcuts for daily decision-making, examining availability and representativeness heuristics through real-world examples including violence perception and medical diagnosis scenarios.
learningOutcomes: Define heuristics as cognitive tools that enable quick decision-making based on past experiences
Explain how availability heuristic can lead to misconceptions about world violence and current events
Understand representativeness heuristic through medical diagnosis probability scenarios
Recognize that intelligence and education do not protect against heuristic-based errors
Analyze how political views can be distorted by overreliance on mental shortcuts
Develop intellectual humility and openness to challenging personal judgments and assumptions

microcontents.title: Understanding Cognitive Biases in UX Design
microcontents.description: Comprehensive presentation examining cognitive biases in UX design practice, exploring the evolutionary purpose of biases, the bias blind spot phenomenon, and practical strategies for creating more inclusive design processes and outcomes.
learningOutcomes: Understand the evolutionary purpose and modern implications of cognitive biases as mental shortcuts
Recognize the bias blind spot phenomenon and its statistical reality (0.15% vs 50% actual bias rates)
Identify how unconscious biases affect design decisions across multiple dimensions (race, gender, culture, etc.)
Analyze real-world examples of bias blind spot in workplace discrimination and expert rejection
Develop systematic approaches for acknowledging, identifying, and addressing personal biases in design work
Implement external feedback mechanisms and checks-and-balances to mitigate unconscious bias impact

microcontents.title: 20 Cognitive Biases That Screw Up Your Decisions
microcontents.description: Visual infographic presenting 20 common cognitive biases with brief explanations and practical examples, covering decision-making errors from anchoring bias to zero-risk bias with illustrative icons and accessible descriptions.
learningOutcomes: Identify 20 common cognitive biases and their basic definitions
Recognize real-world examples of biases like anchoring, availability heuristic, and confirmation bias
Understand how biases affect everyday decisions from salary negotiations to investment choices
Distinguish between different types of biases including social (bandwagon effect), perceptual (clustering illusion), and memory-based (recency)
Apply bias awareness to personal decision-making situations through relatable examples
Build foundational vocabulary for understanding systematic errors in human judgment

microcontents.title: Cognitive Bias in Business Risk Assessment
microcontents.description: Visual mind map illustrating cognitive biases that affect business decision-making and risk assessment, organized around a central brain graphic with categorized biases (social, financial, failure to estimate, short-term) and real business scenarios.
primaryConcepts: status quo bias in change management
learningOutcomes: Categorize cognitive biases into social, financial, estimation, and short-term decision-making contexts
Apply bias concepts to realistic business scenarios including negotiations, team decisions, and risk assessment
Recognize how anchoring effect influences initial business proposals and pricing decisions
Identify confirmation bias patterns in business research and competitor analysis
Understand how availability heuristic affects perception of business risks and opportunities
Connect abstract bias concepts to concrete workplace situations through contextual examples

microcontents.title: Cognitive Bias: Ethics Defined
microcontents.description: Educational video explaining cognitive bias as systematic errors in thinking that affect all people, focusing on overconfidence bias, confirmation bias, anchoring effect, and overgeneralization with emphasis on medical decision-making contexts.
learningOutcomes: Recognize that cognitive biases affect all people regardless of intelligence or education level
Define overconfidence bias and its impact on professional decision-making, particularly in medical diagnosis
Understand confirmation bias as the tendency to process information through existing belief filters
Explain anchoring effect as insufficient adjustment from initial reference points when new information emerges
Identify overgeneralization as drawing broad conclusions from limited evidence
Appreciate that bias awareness and education can reduce but not eliminate cognitive errors

microcontents.title: Confirmation Bias in UX Research: Recognition and Mitigation
microcontents.description: UX research methodology video examining how confirmation bias affects information gathering, interpretation, and communication in UX practice, with practical strategies for minimizing bias impact in design decisions and usability testing.
learningOutcomes: Recognize how confirmation bias affects information gathering in design decision-making processes
Identify confirmation bias patterns in usability test interpretation and stakeholder communication
Apply multiple perspective approaches to minimize bias when researching design solutions
Implement data-rooted documentation practices to counteract subjective interpretation tendencies
Utilize severity scoring systems to objectively communicate research findings and issue priorities
Develop reflective practices for recognizing and reducing personal bias impact in UX research work

microcontents.title: Psychology of Design: 106 Cognitive Biases & Principles Cheatsheet
microcontents.description: Comprehensive reference cheatsheet cataloging 106 cognitive biases and psychological principles that affect UX design, organized by categories (Information, Meaning, Time, Memory) with concise one-liner explanations and emoji icons for quick reference.
learningOutcomes: Access a comprehensive catalog of 106 cognitive biases and psychological principles relevant to UX design
Categorize biases into four main areas: Information processing, Meaning-making, Time-related effects, and Memory
Quickly reference specific biases using visual icons and concise one-liner explanations
Understand the breadth of psychological factors that influence user behavior and decision-making
Apply categorized bias knowledge to different stages of the design process and user journey
Use the cheatsheet as a practical reference tool for identifying potential bias impacts in design decisions

microcontents.title: Machine Learning Bias: How Human Bias Enters AI Systems
microcontents.description: Educational video explaining how human biases infiltrate machine learning systems through interaction bias, latent bias, and selection bias, using relatable examples like shoe recognition and physicist identification to demonstrate bias propagation in AI technology.
learningOutcomes: Understand how machine learning differs from traditional programming in terms of pattern recognition vs step-by-step coding
Identify three main types of bias in machine learning: interaction bias, latent bias, and selection bias
Recognize how interaction bias occurs when user inputs skew training data toward certain demographics or preferences
Explain latent bias as historical prejudices embedded in training datasets that algorithms learn to replicate
Understand selection bias as inadequate representation in chosen training data that excludes certain groups
Appreciate ongoing efforts to prevent bias perpetuation in AI systems and the importance of inclusive technology development

microcontents.title: Overconfidence Bias: Self-Perception vs Reality in Ethics and Abilities
microcontents.description: Educational video examining overconfidence bias as the tendency to overestimate personal abilities and ethical character, including research findings on business professionals' ethical self-assessment and the relationship between overconfidence and unethical behavior.
learningOutcomes: Define overconfidence bias as systematic overestimation of personal abilities and character traits
Recognize overconfidence patterns in practical skills like driving, teaching, and spelling
Understand how overconfidence extends to ethical self-perception and moral character assessment
Analyze research findings showing 50% of business people believe they're in the top 10% ethically
Connect overconfidence bias to overestimation of charitable behaviors and volunteer commitments
Appreciate how overconfidence reduces moral reflection and increases likelihood of unethical actions

microcontents.title: Algorithmic Bias: From Human Prejudice to AI Discrimination
microcontents.description: Comprehensive educational video exploring algorithmic bias origins, real-world examples in hiring and healthcare, the black box problem in AI decision-making, and solutions for creating fair AI systems through inclusive design and algorithmic justice.
learningOutcomes: Understand how human biases transfer into algorithmic systems through design, testing, and application processes
Recognize the 'garbage in, garbage out' principle in AI training data and its impact on system predictions
Analyze real-world examples of algorithmic bias in hiring, criminal justice, healthcare, and facial recognition
Explain the black box problem and why AI decision-making transparency is crucial for bias detection
Evaluate solutions for minimizing algorithmic bias including diverse training data and third-party auditing
Appreciate the role of algorithmic justice advocates like Dr. Joy Buolamwini in promoting inclusive AI development

microcontents.title: Cognitive Biases in Digital Systems: Design Implications and Mitigation Strategies
microcontents.description: Comprehensive guide examining how cognitive biases (confirmation bias, anchoring bias, availability heuristic) manifest in digital systems like search engines and decision support tools, with research-backed design strategies for bias mitigation.
learningOutcomes: Understand how cognitive biases systematically affect user interactions with digital systems and interfaces
Analyze confirmation bias manifestations in search engines and how users selectively engage with confirming information
Recognize anchoring bias effects in decision support systems, particularly in medical and financial applications
Explain how availability heuristic influences user responses to alert systems and risk communication
Apply design strategies to mitigate confirmation bias through diverse perspective presentation and contradictory evidence highlighting
Implement interface solutions for reducing anchoring bias through continuous data updates and comparative information display

microcontents.title: Identifying Cognitive Biases in Real Interfaces: Case Studies and Critical Analysis
microcontents.description: Microlearning module analyzing how real-world digital interfaces (Booking.com, banking apps, AI dashboards) exploit cognitive biases like scarcity, social proof, anchoring, and framing effects, with critical discussion on ethical implications and user autonomy.
learningOutcomes: Identify specific cognitive biases triggered by real digital interfaces through concrete case study analysis
Analyze how Booking.com uses scarcity bias and social proof to influence booking decisions and reduce deliberation time
Recognize anchoring and framing effects in banking applications and their impact on financial decision-making
Understand how AI dashboards can trigger confirmation bias and overconfidence in automated insights
Evaluate the ethical implications of bias exploitation in interface design, particularly regarding user autonomy
Apply bias identification skills to personal app usage through reflective analysis and behavioral self-assessment

microcontents.title: Cognitive Biases Quiz: Definitions and Effects in Digital Systems
microcontents.description: Assessment quiz with 10 multiple-choice questions covering major cognitive biases (anchoring, confirmation, availability, representativeness, framing) and their specific effects in digital systems and decision support contexts.
learningOutcomes: Discriminate between different cognitive bias definitions through multiple-choice assessment
Correctly identify anchoring bias as the tendency to judge based on first received information
Recognize confirmation bias effects in ignoring contradictory information to personal beliefs
Explain availability bias as probability assessment based on mental recall ease
Apply bias knowledge to practical scenarios in decision support systems
Evaluate concrete examples of biases in digital contexts like recommendation systems and user interfaces

microcontents.title: The Overconfidence Bias Case Study: Cognitive Processes in Project Management
microcontents.description: Comprehensive case study following project manager Alex through overconfidence bias formation, systematically analyzing cognitive processes (memory, attention, perception) and System 1 thinking with guided reflection questions.
learningOutcomes: Identify how selective memory and attention processes contribute to overconfidence in professional settings
Interpret the role of automatic categorization and System 1 thinking in creating systematic reasoning errors
Analyze how past success memory bias leads to underestimation of risks and dismissal of alternative perspectives
Evaluate concrete professional scenarios to autonomously identify cognitive processes behind overconfidence bias
